item.title: Brand new unicorn IQM sets its sights beyond Europe for its quantum computers

review.headline_rewrite: Brand new unicorn IQM sets its sights beyond Europe for its quantum computers
bullets: Finnish quantum computing startup IQM is now a unicorn: The company just raised more than $300 million in a Series B funding round that was led by Ten Eleven Ventures, a U.S.
investment firm focused on cybersecurity.
A university spinout, IQM builds quantum computers meant for on-premises installations as well as a cloud platform that taps this hardware.
The company has already sold its quantum computers to enterprises in APAC and the U.S., but its strongest market remains Europe.
According to its co-CEO and co-founder Jan Goetz, this means investing more in the company’s chip fabrication facilities, as well as in software development and error correction research.

Error correction, the ability to detect and fix errors inherent in quantum systems, is a hot topic right now, given that the very notion of what makes a quantum computer competitive is being redefined — being able to compute a large number of qubits is less of a holy grail today than it used to be.

item.title: AI could bring us a smarter home — if we can trust it

review.headline_rewrite: AI could bring us a smarter home — if we can trust it
bullets: The holy grail of the smart home is ambient computing — technology that disappears into the background, anticipating your needs without a word or a tap.

The tools exist to create this, but today’s smart home remains complicated, unreliable, and often invasive — still a long way from truly “ambient.”
AI could bring us a smarter home — if we can trust it
At IFA 2025, tech giants and startups alike will show us their visions for how AI could make connected homes more intuitive, context-aware, and truly ambient.

The rise of AI agents that tap into language and visual models is the technology that could take us from the command-and-control era of home automation to living in the Starship Enterprise, where our every need can be served by Star Trek’s Computer (assuming that’s what you want).
While every announcement will likely feature “AI,” I’ll be looking for those with real potential to make products better, smarter, and easier to use, while keeping data local and private.
I’ve already started to see glimpses of how AI can improve the smart home.
New features on my Ring security cameras, powered by Visual Language Models (VLMs), mean they can tell me what’s happening instead of just showing me.

item.title: IFA 2025: the biggest tech and gadget announcements

review.headline_rewrite: IFA 2025: the biggest tech and gadget announcements
bullets: Companies are gearing up to showcase their latest innovations, bringing us the latest product announcements, feature demonstrations, and design concepts that will shape future consumer tech releases.

And, as always, The Verge will be covering all the latest news live from the IFA 2025 show floor in Berlin, providing you with our hands-on product experiences and first impressions of upcoming releases.

If previous years are any indication, we can expect to see a plethora of new smart home gadgets and AI-laden devices, including laptops, tablets, appliances, and even robots that will do your household chores for you — sometimes equipped with incredibly specialized features.

Samsung may be partly to blame for unleashing the party speaker upon the world — its Giga line launched over a decade ago — but in recent years its entrants to the field have been strangely restrained, with only small light strips along the sides.
Read Article >The holy grail of the smart home is ambient computing — technology that disappears into the background, anticipating your needs without a word or a tap.

The tools exist to create this, but today’s smart home remains complicated, unreliable, and often invasive — still a long way from truly “ambient.”
But, just as it’s changing every other game in tech, advances in artificial intelligence are a watershed moment for the smart home.

item.title: Dolby Atmos FlexConnect Lets You Place Speakers Anywhere

review.headline_rewrite: Dolby Atmos FlexConnect Lets You Place Speakers Anywhere
bullets: But few single-speaker systems live up to the promise of Dolby Atmos, and if you buy a model with additional satellite speakers and subs, the placement of these speakers remains crucial to getting that dome-of-sound experience we associate with movie magic.
In its launch guise, Dolby Atmos FlexConnect uses a smart TV as its central hub.
However, future FlexConnect products may embed that hub function in soundbars or even smart speakers—opening up more options for those who don’t want to replace their TV.

Wireless Dolby Atmos
As Dolby’s launch partner, TCL is the first to embed FlexConnect into a TV.
All of TCL’s 2025 QD-Mini LED TVs are FlexConnect-compatible and can be paired with up to four wireless TCL Z100 FlexConnect speakers, which TCL sells for $400 each.
Naturally, this raises the question of compatibility.

item.title: Puffy Cloud Mattress Review: Soft but Supportive

review.headline_rewrite: Puffy Cloud Mattress Review: Soft but Supportive
bullets: I will admit that, once upon a time, I was not the Puffy Cloud’s biggest supporter.
Granted, during my previous tests, I didn’t spend a whole week sleeping on the Cloud in my own bedroom, as I did this time.
I was knocked out the entire week, and by the end of it, I found I was actually looking forward to receiving a “hug” from the Puffy Cloud.

(If you want to research more first, check out our guide to the best mattresses.)
Head in the Clouds
A lot of Puffy's material names involve clouds.
First is the Cool Touch Cloud Cover, complete with embossed clouds scattered across the surface.
The knitted material is designed to feel cool to the touch and helps prevent the bed from trapping heat, a common complaint about memory foam.

item.title: The best MagSafe power banks for your iPhone

review.headline_rewrite: The best MagSafe power banks for your iPhone
bullets: Read more about how we evaluate products.
Anker’s MagGo power bank was one of the first Qi2-certified products to come to market — and it’s still one of the most well-rounded MagSafe banks you can get.
A small display tells you just how much charge remains (and how long until it’s full when you’re recharging the battery).
The kickstand is sturdy so you can use the phone hands-free in portrait mode, or you can twist the phone to watch something in landscape orientation.
Like many Anker products we’ve tried, it has a sturdy build and a clean aesthetic.
Like all power banks, it slowed down significantly after the pack was half drained, so it’s worth noting that it charged the phone to 40 percent in less than an hour.
